Fig. 1 Effect of different phosphine-oxide organic structures on the performance of Cu-based catalysts for acetylene hydrochlorination. (Reaction conditions: T = 180 ℃, GHSVC2H2 = 180 h−1, and VHCl/VC2H2 = 1.2). Fig. 1 Fig. 2 The stability measurement of 15%Cu7%TPPO/AC catalyst. (Reaction conditions: T = 180 ℃, GHSVC2H2 = 50 h−1, VHCl/VC2H2 = 1.2). Fig. 2 Fig. 3 FT-IR spectra of CuCl2•2H2O, CuCl2-TPPO, and TPPO samples. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 XRD patterns of the AC, fresh catalysts: 15%Cu/AC, 15%Cu7%TPPO/AC and used catalysts: 15%Cu/AC, 15%Cu7%TPPO/AC. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 TEM images of fresh catalysts: 15%Cu/AC (A), 15%Cu7%TPPO/AC (C) and used catalysts: 15%Cu/AC (B), 15%Cu7%TPPO/AC (D). Fig. 5 Fig. 6 Cu 2p XPS spectra of (A) 15%Cu/AC, (B) 15%Cu7%TPPO/AC, and Cu LMM Auger spectra of (C) 15%Cu/AC, (D) 15%Cu7%TPPO/AC. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 H2-TPR profiles of 15%Cu/AC and 15%Cu7%TPPO/AC catalysts. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 The desorption properties of 15%Cu/AC and 15%Cu10%TPPO/AC catalysts to HCl (A), C2H2 (B), and VCM (C). Fig. 8 Fig. 9 TG and DTG curves of catalysts: (A) Fresh and used 15%Cu/AC, (B) Fresh and used 15%Cu7%TPPO/AC. Fig. 9 Fig. 10 The stable structures of CuCl2 (A), TPPO (B), and CuCl2-TPPO (C); the adsorption configurations of CuCl2 clusters for HCl (D), C2H2 (E), and VCM (F); CuCl2-TPPO adsorption configuration for HCl (G), C2H2 (H), VCM (I). Gray, white, orange, red, pink, and green balls represent C, H, P, O, Cu, and Cl atoms, respectively. Fig. 10 Fig. 11 (A) Plots of the RDG isosurface for the structure of HCl and C2H2 both adsorbed by Cu-TPPO; Blue color indicates notable attraction, the green color indicates a weak interaction, and red indicates notable repulsion; (B) Electron density difference (EDD) of Cu complex; the green area represents the electron density increases, and the blue area represents the electron density decreases after complexation. Fig. 11 Fig. 12 DFT calculations (A) Geometric structure of intermediates and transition states. (B) The energy change during the reaction. School of Chemical Engineering and Technology, Tianjin University Tianjin 300072 China Considering the disadvantages of Cu-based catalyst for acetylene hydrochlorination, such as poor dispersion, severe carbon deposition and insufficient active sites, supported Cu-complex catalysts were synthesized by using phosphine-oxide organic compounds as ligands. A local active domain was successfully constructed based on the complexation of Cu atom to heteroatomic structure in meticulously selected ligands, in which the phenyl group acts as an electron donor to change the CuCl2 active site electronic structure. The density functional theory calculation proved the existence of a strong interaction between triphenylphosphine oxide and CuCl2, and synchronously, electrons on the benzene ring were transferred to the Cl atom in CuCl2, stabilizing the Cu species. This superior activity may be attributed to the heightened adsorption of HCl and weakened C2H2 and vinyl chloride adsorption by the constructed local active domain, which impedes the carbon deposition that promotes the continuous exposure of active sites. Under the reaction conditions: T = 180 ℃, GHSVC2H2 = 180 h−1 and VHCl/VC2H2 = 1.2, the C2H2 conversion of 15%Cu7%TPPO/AC reaches 88%, which was over 30% higher than 15%Cu/AC catalyst. The significantly improved activity and stability of the proposed catalyst provides a reference for green and sustainable production of vinyl chloride. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Acetylene hydrochlorination Local active domain Cu catalyst DFT calculation Phosphine-oxide organic ligand 1 Introduction Vinyl chloride monomer (VCM) is widely used in polymer chemistry as important monomer, particularly in the synthesis of polyvinyl chloride. VCM is mainly derived from acetylene hydrochlorination in countries with abundant coal resources [1,2]. Currently, the catalyst for acetylene hydrochlorination used in the industry is HgCl2/AC. However, mercury chloride (HgCl2) is a highly toxic compound with a pungent odor, which will volatilize at the operating temperatures. Hg volatilization can easily cause severe harm to the human body and the environment, and it is inconsistent with green sustainable development [3,4]. Therefore, exploring an effective and environmentally friendly Hg-free catalyst to promote the long-term growth of acetylene hydrochlorination is critical. In 1985, Hutchings believed that the catalytic performance of metal chloride catalysts in acetylene hydrochlorination is related to the standard potential of metal cations [5]. Whereafter, the sequence of activity for metal chloride catalysts in acetylene hydrochlorination was obtained: Au > Pd > Ru > Ir > Pt > Rh [6]. After years of research, various metal catalysts, including Au [7–9], Ru [10–12], Pd [13,14], Cu [15] and other metals [16–18], etc., have been successively used in the acetylene hydrochlorination, with expectations of replacing HgCl2. However, precious metals such as Au, Ru, and Pd will increase production costs, hence, Cu, a nonprecious metal has been logically locked as a research focus [19–21]. Currently, the catalytic performance of Cu is mainly improved through support functionalization and adding metal promoters and ligands. The support modification is conducted by heteroatom doping, particularly with nonmetallic elements such as N and P. For example, Zhou et al. prepared Cu-NCNT catalysts with N-doped carbon nanotubes and revealed that N-doping effectively improved the electronic conductivity of carbon, strengthened the interaction of Cu and N-CNTs, promoted the adsorption of C2H2, and increased the catalytic activity. At 180 ℃, the GHSVC2H2 = 180 h−1 and VHCl/VC2H2 = 1.1, the C2H2 conversion of 5 wt% Cu-NCNT catalyst was about 43.5% [22]. Zhao et al. investigated the effect of N in Cu-g-C3N4/AC catalyst, and concluded that Cu enhanced the content of pyrrole N, which increased HCl adsorption and thus promoted the C2H2 conversion. The C2H2 conversion of Cu-g-C3N4/AC catalyst reached 79% at 180 ℃ and GHSVC2H2 = 72 h−1, which remained unchanged during the 7.5 h reaction [23]. A phosphorus-doped Cu catalyst supported on spherical activated carbon was synthesized and illustrated that the doping of phosphorus suppresses the aggregation of Cu nanoparticles, improving its catalytic stability [24]. Under the condition of 15 wt% Cu loading, 140 °C, GHSVC2H2 = 180 h−1 and VHCl/VC2H2 = 1.15, the C2H2 conversion was 72.4%. Although the support modification can improve the activity of the catalyst, the range of improvement is limited. The catalyst’s stability still needs to be improved. Metal auxiliaries can also help improve the catalytic performance of metal catalysts by altering the electronic structure. Xu et al. prepared Cu-Ru/MWCNTs catalyst using the co-impregnation method. At T = 180 ℃, and GHSVC2H2 = 180 h−1, the C2H2 conversion of Cu400Ru/MWCNTs was up to 51.6% [25]. Zhai et al. prepared a highly performance catalyst based on CsCuCl3 complex supported AC. The activity of Cu-Cs/AC catalyst was above 58%, which was 2.8 times that of Cu/AC catalyst. The CsCuCl3 structure formed with Cs as an electron donor and Cu as a receptor stabilized Cu2+ and increased the adsorption capacity of HCl [26]. Compared with Cu/AC catalyst, bimetallic catalyst regulated the electronic structure of Cu catalyst by adding metal promoter, and increased the adsorption performance of reactants, resulting in significantly improved catalytic performance, particularly stability, but it falls short of industry requirements. The main purpose of heteroatomic or co-metal doping is to adjust the electronic structure of Cu. Ligand coordination can also alter the electronic structure of Cu, while maintaining good stability. For example, Yu et al. used an ionic liquid (IL) as the reaction medium and CuCl2 as the catalyst to prove that IL and Cu (II) active catalytic species had a strong synergistic effect. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations showed that CuCl2 was adsorbed near the N atom of 1-propenyl-3-methylimidazolium chloride ([PrMIm]Cl), and the main catalytic reaction occurred on the Cu (II) active site [27]. Ren et al. synthesized several cuprate ILs to improve the performance of Cu catalysts. N-methylpyrrolidinium hydrochloride-0.60CuCl ([Hnmpo]Cl-0.60CuCl) showed the best catalytic performance. At 180 ℃ and GHSVC2H2 = 50 h−1, the C2H2 maintains 86% conversion after 150 h [28]. Wang et al. reported that the (Methoxymethyl)triphenylphosphonium chloride (MOMTPPC) IL can significance improve the catalytic performance of heterogeneous Cu-based catalysts. Under the reaction conditions of T = 180 ℃, and VHCl/VC2H2 = 1.2, the C2H2 conversion of 15%Cu@ 15%MOMTPPC/SAC was 92.2%. Under the condition of industrial GHSVC2H2 = 36 h−1, the C2H2 conversion remained 98.7% up to 360 h [29]. This demonstrates that ligands can improve the performance of Cu catalyst, hence much study has been done to identify a suitable ligand that can satisfy the industrial requirements. Heteroatom functionalization and ligand coordination can effectively improve catalytic performance. Therefore, the focus has switched back to organic ligands containing heteroatoms. Wang et al. using 1-hydroxyethylidene-1, 1-diphosphonic acid (HEDP) as a phosphorus-containing ligand prepared a Cu-HEDP/AC catalyst. When GHSVC2H2 = 90 h−1, the C2H2 conversion reached 83.35%, which was 25.87% higher than Cu/AC catalyst [30]. The addition of HEDP inhibited the reduction of high-valence Cu and improved the dispersion of the active component. However, the addition of the HEDP ligand did not effectively reduce the generation of carbon deposits, resulting in poor stability of the Cu-HEDP/AC catalyst. Wang et al. prepared several Cu-pyrrolidone/SAC catalysts. The results showed that N-Methyl-2-Pyrrolidinone (NMP) could remarkably improve the stability of Cu catalyst. Under industrial conditions, the C2H2 conversion of Cu-0.25NMP/SAC maintained above 99.1% in about 220 h [31]. Zhao et al. attributed the high activity of the NMP-coordinated Cu-based catalyst to the interaction between the ligand and CuCl2 based on experimental and DFT results. The NMP ligand destroyed the resting state, making the overall reaction barrier lower than Cu(I)/AC catalysts [32]. Hu et al. used phosphamide as a ligand to obtain a Cu-based catalyst with high catalytic performance. They also proved that Cu and O in the HMPA ligand form stable coordination bonds, thus stabilizing the valence state of the active component [33]. From the reported literatures, we found that organic ligands containing oxygen can effectively promote the performance of Cu catalysts in acetylene hydrochlorination. Moreover, the ligand’s electron-donating capacity should not be too high, since this will result in an increase in electrons on Cu and a decrease in the valence state of Cu, resulting in the catalyst’s deactivation. Thus, we selected phosphine oxide organic ligands with a weak electron-donating ability to regulate the electronic structure of the Cu-based catalyst. It was found that triphenylphosphine oxide could form a stable complex with CuCl2, which greatly improved the performance and stability of the Cu catalyst. We have performed several characterizations to explain the relationship between the structure and catalytic performance. The complex’s adsorption to the reactants and products as well as the change in electronic structure caused by ligand and the reaction mechanism under the action of the complex were analyzed using DFT calculation. 2 Experiment and methods 2.1 Materials AC (20–40 mesh) was supplied by Nanping Sensen Carbon Industry Co., Ltd. Nitrogen (N2, 99.999%) and acetylene (C2H2, 99.999%) were procured from Tianjin Huanyu Gas Co., Ltd. Hydrogen chloride (HCl, 99.999%) and vinyl chloride (CH2CHCl, 99.99%) were provided by Tianjin Dongxiang Special Gas Co., Ltd. Hydrochloric acid (HCl aqueous solution, 36.0–38.0 wt%) was supplied by Tianjin Fengchuan Chemical Reagent Technology Co., Ltd. Diphenyl Phosphine oxide (DPPO, 98%) and cupric chloride dehydrate (CuCl2·H2O, 99%) were supplied by Tianjin Ciense Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd. Triphenylphosphine oxide (TPPO, ≥98%) and trismorpholinophosphine oxide (TMPO, ≥98%) were sourced from Shanghai Dibo Biotechnology Co., Ltd. 2,4,6-trimethylbenzoyldiphenylphosphinoxide (TMDPO, 97%) was supplied by Kmart (Tianjin) Chemical Technology Co., Ltd. Tripyrrolidinophosphine oxide (TPDPO, ≥98%) was produced by Adamas Reagent Co., Ltd. All chemical substances were used directly without further purification. 2.2 Catalyst preparation An incipient impregnation method was used to prepare catalyst, and the mass percentage of Cu and TPPO was calculated based on AC. First, soak the AC in a 1 M hydrochloric acid solution in a 60 °C water bath for 6 h. Then, collect the AC by filtration, wash it with deionized water to become neutrality, and dry it in an oven at 150 °C. 0.5 g of ligand TPPO is added to 9 mL of ethanol. When TPPO is completely dissolved, 2.012 g of CuCl2·2H2O is added to the solution. Stir for half an hour to make it react completely with the ligand, and then slowly add 5 g of dried AC to the solution. Seal with plastic wrap and place in a 60 ℃ water bath. After 6 h, remove the plastic wrap and continue heating for another 6 h. Transfer the sample to a 120 ℃ oven and leave it to dry overnight. The resulting catalyst sample is labeled 15%Cu10%TPPO/AC. TPPO is replaced with other ligands to prepare different ligand catalysts based on the aforementioned procedure, and catalysts with different ligand contents are prepared by varying the TPPO quantity. 2.3 Characterization The catalyst samples were characterized to understand the changes in the catalyst before and after the reaction as well as to analyze the catalyst’s structure and the major factors affecting the catalytic performance. Low temperature adsorption and desorption tests were worked in the AutosorbiQ2 specific surface area analyzer of Quantachrome Company to obtain the sample’s structural parameters. The sample was first degassed at 200 °C for 6 h and then performed low-temperature helium adsorption-desorption analysis in liquid nitrogen (−196 °C) with relative pressure (P/Po) ranging from 0.01 to 1.0 (ca. 55 points). The dispersion and size of Cu particles in the sample were obtained from the JEM-F200 field-emission transmission electron microscope (TEM) from JEOL Company. The carbon deposited on the catalyst during the reaction was evaluated using the Swiss Mettler Toledo TGA/DSC-2 START thermogravimetric analyzer (TGA). The crystal structure of the sample was analyzed using the Rigaku Smartlab X-ray diffractometer (XRD). The information of molecular structure was obtained from the vertex Fourier Transform Infrared (FT-IR) Spectrometer from the German Bruker instrument company. The valence state and composition of the metal on the sample surface were measured on an X-ray photoelectron spectrometer (XPS) of K-Alpha+ by UK ThermoFisher Scientific. The desorption properties of catalysts to HCl, C2H2 and VCM as well as the reduction ability and metal dispersion of the catalyst samples with 10 vol% H2/Ar gas, were studied using the U.S. Quantachrome Company AutoChem BET TPR/TPD chemisorption instrument. 2.4 Catalytic performance testing Acetylene hydrochlorination reaction was performed in a fixed bed reactor. The size of the reaction tube is ϕ10 × 500 mm. A 4 mL catalyst sample was placed in the reaction tube’s constant temperature section. N2 was introduced into the reaction tube to remove the air from reaction tube, which was then heated to 180 ℃. N2 was subsequently turned off and HCl was added for 30 min to activate catalysts. C2H2 and HCl were injected into the reactor according to GHSVC2H2 = 180 h−1 and VHCl/VC2H2 = 1.2. The reaction tube’s outlet was connected with NaOH absorbing liquid and anhydrous CaCl2 dryer to remove unreacted HCl and water, and finally the reacted gas was detected using gas chromatography. The space velocity of 50 h−1 was used when performing long-life experiments. 2.5 DFT calculations DFT calculations were implemented in the Gaussian 09 package [34] using the Becke-3-Lee-Yang-Parr (B3LYP) functional [35]. The def2-TZVP basis set was applied for the Cu atom. For all other atoms, the def-TZVP basis set was used for geometric optimization, and the def2-TZVP basis set was applied to calculate single-point energy. The D3 dispersion correction was applied to account for long-range dispersion interactions [36]. The convergence criteria of structural optimization and transition state (TS) search adopts Gaussian 09 default setting. The adsorption energies of reactants and products on the catalyst were defined as: (1) E ads = E sys − E mol − E cat Where E ads represents the adsorption energy; E sys is the total energy of the system composed of adsorbates and catalyst; E mol is the energy of the adsorbates in the ideal gas phase, and E cat is the energy of the catalyst. The local energy minima and TS were confirmed by vibrational frequency calculations, and the reliability of the TS connecting two minima was further checked by intrinsic reaction coordinate (IRC) calculations [37–39]. To better understand the reaction mechanism, the analyses of Mulliken charge, RDG isosurface, and electron density difference (EDD) were conducted using the Multiwfn 3.7 software [40]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic reactivity First, the effect of different phosphine-oxide organic structures on the performance of the Cu catalyst for the acetylene hydrochlorination reaction was investigated with constant Cu loading and ligand quality. The results are shown in Fig. 1. The ability to improve the C2H2 conversion for different ligands is DPPO > TPPO > TMPO > TMDPO > TPDPO. Fig. 1A shows that the initial C2H2 conversion rate of the 15%Cu/AC catalyst was about 55%, which decreased to 44% after a 12 h reaction. The catalytic activity and stability were significantly improved after adding the ligand. The ability of DPPO to improve the C2H2 conversion was most significant. The catalytic performance had been increased by about 30% compared with the 15%Cu/AC catalyst. However, although the initial activity of 15%Cu10%DPPO/AC catalyst was indeed slightly higher than that of 15%Cu10%TPPO/AC catalyst, its stability was relatively poor. After 12 h of reaction, the acetylene conversion of 15%Cu10%DPPO/AC decreased from 88% to 83%, with an inactivation rate of 5.68%, which is higher than the deactivation rate of 15%Cu10%TPPO/AC catalyst (1.19%). Fig. 1B shows that the selectivity of different catalysts to VCM was above 99%. Therefore, TPPO was chosen as optimal ligand in this work. Moreover, the 15%Cu10%TPPO/AC catalyst also had better catalytic performance compared with the catalysts reported in the literatures (Table S1), considering the reaction test conditions, Cu and ligand loading and the economy of the carrier. Therefore, the optimal catalyst in this work is thought to be one of the most probable alternatives to the Hg catalyst on the acetylene hydrochlorination reaction on account of its activity and stability. The effect of the amount of ligand TPPO added to the Cu-based catalyst on acetylene hydrochlorination was further investigated, and the results are shown in Fig. S1. The initial conversions of 17% and 55% were observed for the 7%TPPO/AC and 15%Cu/AC catalysts, respectively, which can be reached to 88% over the 15%Cu7%TPPO/AC catalyst, implying that the high activity of 15%Cu7%TPPO/AC was due to the interaction between Cu and TPPO. Additionally, the C2H2 conversion increased at first and then decreased, and the stability gradually improved as the amount of TPPO increased. The 15%Cu7%TPPO/AC catalyst exhibited the highest C2H2 conversion, however, the C2H2 conversion declined when the TPPO exceeded 7 wt%, and the stability of the catalyst barely changed. This may be attributed to the excessive loading of ligands, which covered part of the active sites and blocked part of the micropore, thus reducing the specific surface area. In addition, the VCM selectivity of the 7%TPPO/AC catalyst was about 93%, whereas that of all the Cu-containing catalysts was more than 99% (Fig. S1B). In summary, the ligand TPPO can remarkably improve the catalytic performance of the Cu-based catalyst, and 15%Cu7%TPPO/AC catalyst exhibited the best performance. Fig. 2 shows the results of the long-term stability test conducted to evaluate the stability of the 15%Cu7%TPPO/AC catalyst. The initial activity of 15%Cu7%TPPO/AC was 99%, which can still be maintained at 94% After a 327-h long-term testing, with a deactivation rate of 0.017% h−1. In addition, the VCM selectivity was higher than 99% without any decrease, and it had better stability than the previously reported catalysts [30–33]. Therefore, the 15%Cu7%TPPO/AC catalyst had an outstanding catalytic performance and had the potential to replace the HgCl2 catalyst in the acetylene hydrochlorination. 3.2 Characterization of prepared samples The catalysts before and after the reaction were characterized in various ways to understand the main factors affecting the catalytic performance and provide guidance for subsequent research. The FT-IR patterns of the samples were collected to prove the interaction between the ligand TPPO and CuCl2. The support was not introduced in the process of testing to eliminate its interference. Fig. 3 shows the infrared spectra of the three samples CuCl2·2H2O, CuCl2-TPPO and TPPO in the ethanol solution. The difference between the three samples could be observed from the patterns. The most notable difference was that in the ligand TPPO spectrum, an obvious absorption peak of PO structure at 1192 cm−1 was observed [41,42], but this peak was not seen in the CuCl2-TPPO spectrum, which was due to the destruction of the PO bond by the interaction between the ligand and Cu, indicating the formation of local active domain coordinated by the ligand and the Cu species. Fig. 4 displays the XRD patterns of the catalyst samples. The AC support had two relatively obvious broad peaks, which were attributed to the diffraction peaks of the AC on the (001) and (101) planes at 24.4° and 43.5°, respectively [43]. On the fresh 15%Cu/AC and 15%Cu7%TPPO/AC catalysts, except for the diffraction peaks of amorphous carbon, there were no characteristic peaks of other substances, indicating that the Cu and Cu-TPPO complexes particles were tiny and uniformly dispersed on AC, which was smaller than the XRD detection limit (4 nm). It also shows that the addition of Cu and TPPO did not evidently change the amorphous structure of AC. The diffraction peak of the loaded catalyst was significantly weakened compared with the diffraction peak of AC at 43.8°. This may be because the Cu and its complex covered part of the AC after loading, which weakened the amorphous shape of the AC. There were distinguishable diffraction peaks corresponded to the crystalline diffraction of basic copper chloride (Cu2(OH)3Cl) on the used-15%Cu/AC catalysts at 2θ of 16.2°, 32.6° and 40.1°, respectively [24]. The generation and aggregation of Cu2(OH)3Cl is an important reason for the inactivation of Cu-based catalyst. As can be seen from Fig. 4, only used-15%Cu/AC sample had a weak diffraction peak of Cu2(OH)3Cl. These results indicated that TPPO can effectively inhibit the formation and agglomeration of Cu2(OH)3Cl, thus improving the stability of Cu-based catalysts. TEM analysis of the catalyst samples was conducted to understand the particle size and dispersion of Cu on the catalyst under the microscopic morphology, and the results are shown in Fig. 5. It can be seen from the figure that there was no large agglomeration of Cu particles on all test samples, indicating an excellent dispersion of Cu species for all catalysts. Compared with the 15%Cu/AC catalyst, after adding the ligand TPPO, the Cu particles on the catalyst reduced significantly from 4.86 to 3.82 nm, indicating that the ligand addition reduced the Cu particles’ sizes and ensured better dispersion. The Cu particles before and after reaction on the 15%Cu/AC and 15%Cu7%TPPO/AC catalyst increased from 4.86 to 5.27 nm, and from 3.82 to 4.58 nm, respectively. This is mainly due to the part of copper aggregate under high temperature, which is also one of the reasons that cause the deactivation. Thus, the addition of ligands improved the reaction performance of the catalyst by promoting the dispersion of Cu species on AC. The chemical state and content of Cu in the catalyst before and after the reaction were analyzed by XPS and X-ray-induced Auger electron spectroscopy (XAES). There were two fitting peaks in the fitting curve shown in Fig. 6 (A and B). The fitting peak at 932.9 eV corresponds to Cu+ and Cu0 species, whereas the fitting peak at 935.0 eV corresponds to Cu2+, implying that the prepared catalyst contains Cu+, Cu0, and Cu2+ with or without ligands [44]. From the XAES fitting curve shown in Fig. 6 (C and D), Cu+ and Cu0 can be clearly distinguished. The peak at 918.4 eV corresponds to the Cu0 species, whereas the peak at 915.4 eV corresponds to the Cu+ species [31,45]. The Cu2+ and Cu+ had similar acetylene hydrochlorination reaction activity, so the change of Cu0 content was mainly investigated [5,46]. Table 1 lists the Cu2+, Cu+, and Cu0 contents obtained by integrating over the area. The data in Table 1 shows that after adding TPPO, the number of Cu2+ and Cu+ increases, but the amount of Cu0 decreases. This is due to the three benzene rings on TPPO increasing the ligand’s electron cloud density, and the electrons are transported to the CuCl2 when the complex is formed. Notably, the relative Cu0 content in the catalyst increased after the reaction. By comparing that in the reacted and reacted catalysts, the relative content of Cu0 in 15%Cu/AC catalyst was increased from 5.88% to 8.89%, while the relative content of Cu0 in 15%Cu7%TPPO/AC catalyst was increased from 2.82% to 4.15%, indicating that the addition of ligand inhibited the reduction of Cu species in the preparation and reaction processes, and more Cu species were kept in the oxidation state, thus improving the stability of the catalyst. Combined with the performance of the catalyst in Fig. S1, it is proved that the reduction of the oxidation state of Cu in the catalyst is one of the causes of catalyst deactivation. Fig. 7 shows the H2-TPR profiles for 15%Cu/AC and 15%Cu7%TPPO/AC catalysts. In the profiles, the 15%Cu/AC catalyst exhibits three reduction peaks at 350 ℃, 430 ℃, and 518 ℃ respectively, corresponding to the force between Cu and the support, Cu2+ reduction, and Cu+ reduction. These three reduction peaks can also be observed on the 15%Cu7%TPPO/AC catalyst. Notably, an additional reduction peak is observed at 600 °C, which is generated by hydrogen consumption on account of the reduction of oxygen-containing functional groups on the ligand. Simultaneously, the intensity of the reduction peak of 15%Cu7%TPPO/AC catalyst was increased compared with 15%Cu/AC, indicating an increase in the dispersion of Cu on the support due to the addition of TPPO, as well as an increase in the content of oxidized Cu species in the 15%Cu7%TPPO/AC catalyst. The addition of TPPO increased the content and dispersion of Cu active species, which explains why the activity of the 15%Cu7%TPPO/AC was higher than that of the 15%Cu/AC catalyst. The desorption performance of the catalyst for HCl, C2H2 and VCM was tested by a temperature-programmed desorption experiment, and the results are shown in Fig. 8. Desorption temperature reflects the adsorption strength, and the area of desorption peak represents the amount of adsorption. From the figure compared with 15%Cu/AC catalyst, the area of HCl desorption peak corresponding to 15%Cu10%TPPO/AC catalyst was significantly increased, and the areas of C2H2 and VCM desorption peaks was significantly decreased, indicating that the TPPO prominently increased the HCl adsorption and weakened the adsorption of C2H2 and VCM. The enhanced adsorption of HCl improved the reaction performance, the weaker adsorption of C2H2 inhibited carbon deposition, and the weakened adsorption of VCM improved product desorption, thus increasing the active site usage rate. The main reason for these changes was that the benzene ring in TPPO was an electron-donating group that transferred electrons to the local active domain via the PO structure thus changing the electronic structure of the active site. The pore texture of the catalyst before and after the reaction was characterized via N2 adsorption and desorption tests, and the results were displayed in Table 2. The specific surface area of AC was 1381 m2 g−1 and the pore volume was 0.71 m3 g−1. The specific surface area and pore volume decreased after Cu was loaded or the ligand was added. On the one hand, it is due to the addition of CuCl2 and ligands covered part of the pore structure, and on the other hand, it is caused by dilution effect [47–49]. Compared with the fresh catalyst, the specific surface area and pore volume of the used catalyst were also reduced, which could be caused by carbon deposition during the reaction [50]. Compared with 15%Cu/AC catalyst, the changes in the specific surface area and pore volume of 15%Cu7%TPPO/AC catalyst were significantly weakened, indicating that the addition of TPPO could inhibit carbon deposition. In published reports, excessive adsorption of C2H2 will promote carbon deposition and cover the active sites on the catalyst, leading to catalyst deactivation. Additionally, the high electron density of Cu facilitated the activation of CC bonds and enhanced the activity of the C2H2 dimerization reaction. The carbon deposited on the catalyst was analyzed by TGA, and the result is shown in Fig. 9. Fig. 9A and B show the TGA experimental results of 15%Cu/AC and 15%Cu7%TPPO/AC catalysts, respectively. Fig. 9 shows that the sample exhibited significant mass loss between the room temperature and 100 ℃, which is due to the evaporation of water absorbed on the surface of the catalyst sample [12]. The mass loss around 100–270 °C was caused by the carbon deposits formed during the reaction. When the temperature was higher than 270 °C, the quality of the sample decreased rapidly due to the combustion of AC and ligand decomposition. Therefore, the mass loss of the catalyst between 100 °C and 270 °C was selected to calculate the carbon deposits during the reaction. The carbon deposits of the 15%Cu/AC and 15%Cu7%TPPO/AC catalysts were 7.12% and 4.96%, respectively. The activity test results of the 15%Cu/AC and 15%Cu7%TPPO/AC catalysts in Fig. 1 showed that the addition of TPPO significantly increased the C2H2 conversion and improved the stability of the catalyst. This is because the addition of TPPO suppressed the generation of carbon deposits. 3.3 Simulating computation DFT simulation was used to optimize the structure of CuCl2, TPPO, and CuCl2-TPPO, and calculate the adsorption energy of HCl, C2H2 and VCM, searching for the transition state of the catalyst in the reaction process to better understanding the adsorption and desorption performance of the catalyst on the reactants HCl, C2H2 and product VCM, as well as the mechanism of the catalyst in the reaction process. Fig. 10 shows the stable structures of CuCl2, TPPO, CuCl2-TPPO, and the adsorption configurations of CuCl2 clusters and CuCl2-TPPO for HCl, C2H2, and VCM. Table 3 lists the adsorption energy of CuCl2 clusters and CuCl2-TPPO for HCl, C2H2, and VCM. From the data, it can be concluded that after adding TPPO, the adsorption energy of HCl decreased from − 6.84 kcal·mol−1 to − 8.97 kcal·mol−1, the adsorption energy of C2H2 increased from − 10.84 kcal·mol−1 to − 6.28 kcal·mol−1, the adsorption energy of VCM decreased from − 12.01 kcal·mol−1 to − 9.22 kcal·mol−1, and the CuCl2-TPPO catalyst increased the adsorption of HCl. However, it weakened the adsorption of C2H2 and VCM, which was more favorable to the progress of the reaction, resulting in improved activity and stability. The charge changes of the main atoms during the formation of the Cu complex were analyzed. Table 4 shows that after the complex was formed, the electrons on the Cl atoms increased, whereas the electrons on the P decreased. The table also shows that the electrons were transferred from the ligand to the CuCl2, increasing its electron density. Compared with CuCl2, the charge of the Cu atom in the Cu complex remained unchanged, but that on the Cl atom decreased, indicating that electrons provided by TPPO were mainly transferred to Cl atom. By comparing the charge changes in Figs. S2 and S3, it can be clearly seen that the benzene ring on the ligand is the electron donor and copper chloride is the electron acceptor. The charge changes of Cu atoms and surrounding atoms were further investigated in detail, and the results are shown in Table S2. The focus was on the electron changes that occurred when Cu atoms adsorb HCl and C2H2. It can be seen from Table S2 that after the CuCl2 cluster adsorbed HCl and C2H2, the charges on the Cu atoms at the adsorption sites decreased from 0.466 eV to 0.295 eV and 0.378 eV, respectively, indicating that the electron on the Cu and Cl atoms was increased, which is due to that the electrons transferred from the reactant to CuCl2, causing catalyst reduction after the reaction. However, the electrons on the Cu complex remained unchanged, stabilizing the electron density on Cu atoms. The interaction force between the atoms in the Cu-TPPO ligand can be observed through the colored isosurface diagram, as shown in Fig. 11(A). The blue color indicates either a relatively strong weak interaction or a chemical bond; The green color indicates the van der Waals area; the reddish color indicates a positioning resistance, and the bright red color indicates a strong steric hindrance, and the bluish color indicates a significant attraction, such as hydrogen bonds and halogen bonds of general strength. Apparently, a strong force between Cu and TPPO was observed, and combined with the redshift of PO in the FT-IR spectrum (Fig. 3), a chemical bond was believed to be formed between Cu and O atoms. Moreover, a hydrogen bond was formed between the H on the HCl and the Cl on the CuCl2, and there was also a strong weak interaction between the C on the C2H2 and the Cu on the CuCl2. On the one hand, it shows that Cu and TPPO formed a complex. On the other hand, it shows that the Cu-TPPO complex could adsorb the HCl and C2H2. The structural changes of CuCl2 and TPPO complex were further studied, and we draw the electron density difference diagram, as shown in Fig. 11(B). It can be clearly seen from the electron density difference graph that the electron density of the Cu atom in the Cu-O direction decreased after the formation of the complex, indicating that a relative positive charge was increased, and C2H2 was easier to adsorb in this direction. The electron density on the outer side of the Cl atom was significantly increased, making it easier to adsorb HCl, which is consistent with the constructed adsorption configuration. The transition states were searched by DFT for acetylene hydrochlorination using CuCl2-TPPO structure as the catalyst. Fig. 12 shows the geometric configuration and energy distribution of intermediates and TS during the reaction. CuCl2 was adsorbed on oxygen atoms to form the active center of the catalyst [32]. Further, HCl and C2H2 simultaneously adsorbed CuCl2 to form a Co-ads structure. HCl was adsorbed on Cl atoms through hydrogen bonds, and C2H2 was adsorbed on Cu atoms. After that, two carbon atoms on C2H2 as well as Cu and Cl atoms on CuCl2 formed a four-membered ring to form transition state TS1, and then a Cl atom on CuCl2 was transferred to the C atom of C2H2 to form intermediate IM1. This process was required to overcome the 15.93 kcal·mol−1 energy barrier, which was considered to be the reaction rate control step. Interestingly, compared to the Co-ads structure, the C atoms on C2H2 was closer to Cu (Cu-Cl bond length shorten from 2.545 Å to 2.027 Å), while the Cu-Cl bond length was increased from 2.212 Å to 2.275 Å, implying that C2H2 was inserted into Cu-Cl. Subsequently, the Cl atom of HCl was close to the Cu atom, and the H atom on the HCl migrated to the C atom of C2H2Cl through the four-membered metal ring transition state TS2, so that the product VCM was adsorbed on the Cu atom, and finally VCM was desorbed from the catalyst to complete the entire reaction. 4 Conclusions Herein, xCu-yTPPO/AC catalysts were prepared to effectively improve acetylene hydrochlorination using a simple impregnation method. Under the same conditions, 15%Cu7%TPPO/AC catalyst improved the C2H2 conversion over 30% at 180 h−1, and exhibited higher stability than 15%Cu/AC catalyst. The C2H2 conversion of 15%Cu7%TPPO/AC decreased from 99.2% to 93.6% after 327 h reaction under the condition of GHSVC2H2 = 50 h−1. The TPPO promotes Cu dispersion, while inhibiting carbon deposition. It has been confirmed that electrons transfer from the benzene ring on the TPPO to the Cl on CuCl2, increasing the adsorption of HCl by the catalyst while weakening the adsorption of C2H2 and VCM, inhibiting the formation of carbon deposits, and maintaining excellent activity and stability. The DFT calculations are consistent with the experimental results, providing a novel approach to the study of Cu-based acetylene hydrochlorination catalysts, and are projected to eventually replace Hg catalysts in the industrial production of VCM. coredata.dc:description: Considering the disadvantages of Cu-based catalyst for acetylene hydrochlorination, such as poor dispersion, severe carbon deposition and insufficient active sites, supported Cu-complex catalysts were synthesized by using phosphine-oxide organic compounds as ligands. A local active domain was successfully constructed based on the complexation of Cu atom to heteroatomic structure in meticulously selected ligands, in which the phenyl group acts as an electron donor to change the CuCl2 active site electronic structure. The density functional theory calculation proved the existence of a strong interaction between triphenylphosphine oxide and CuCl2, and synchronously, electrons on the benzene ring were transferred to the Cl atom in CuCl2, stabilizing the Cu species. This superior activity may be attributed to the heightened adsorption of HCl and weakened C2H2 and vinyl chloride adsorption by the constructed local active domain, which impedes the carbon deposition that promotes the continuous exposure of active sites. Under the reaction conditions: T = 180 ℃, GHSVC2H2 = 180 h−1 and VHCl/VC2H2 = 1.2, the C2H2 conversion of 15%Cu7%TPPO/AC reaches 88%, which was over 30% higher than 15%Cu/AC catalyst. The significantly improved activity and stability of the proposed catalyst provides a reference for green and sustainable production of vinyl chloride.
coredata.dc:title: Phosphine-oxide organic ligand improved Cu-based catalyst for acetylene hydrochlorination
